column1: Don't use words in the dictionary
column2: This leaves you vulnerable to a dictionary attack.
A dictionary attack is a method of breaking into a password-protected computer or server by systematically entering every word in a dictionary as a password.
Minimum of 11 characters.
Once an exhaustive (brute force) password search begins, the most important factor is password length.
This is because short passwords (<5-7 characters) can easily be cracked using a brute force attack alone.
(A brute force attack is one that tries every possible combination of letters, numbers and symbols)

column2: Passwords must contain at least one of each of the following: one alphabetic uppercase, one alphabetic lowercase, one numeric, and one special character.

If an exclamation point is added:

Since most users will likely always be choosing all lowercase characters you'll want to stay as far away from that as possible. And, similarly, the fewest number of users will ever be using many special symbol characters. So the wisest attacker will aim for the herd, searching through lowercase passwords first and symbol-oriented passwords last. Since this is one race which you want to finish last (meaning never) using more symbol characters is highly recommended.

column1: But don't simply stick a string of numbers on the end of your existing password
column2: Especially if it's your year of birth. Crackers will try passwords like 'keith1985' early on.
Using number strings at the end of words leaves you vulnerable to hybrid attacks.
A hybrid attack marries a dictionary attack with a brute-force attack.
For example:
A cracker can append all possible four-characters strings containing digits or symbols to the end of each word in his dictionary

column1: Be creative with the positioning special characters
column2: Put numbers, caps and symbols at unusual points in the middle of the word for added security.
I!waNt387you

Passwords show surprising uniformity when it comes to the types of characters used in each position—in general, capital letters come at the beginning, lower-case letters come in the middle, and symbols and numbers come at the end.
This leaves them vulnerable to Markov attacks.
A Markov attack makes highly educated guesses. It analyzes plains to determine where certain types of characters are likely to appear in a password.

column1: But don't build your password entirely out of special characters
column2: Not only symbols, since you first want to have every type of character represented to force a “full depth” search.

column1: Your password doesn't have to be difficult to remember
column2: Which of the following two passwords is stronger,
more secure, and more difficult to crack?
PrXyc.N(n4k77#L!eVdAfp9

You probably know this is a trick question, but the answer is: Despite the fact that the first password is HUGELY easier to use and more memorable, it is also the stronger of the two! In fact, since it is one character longer and contains uppercase, lowercase, a number and special characters, that first password would take an attacker approximately 95 times longer to find by searching than the second impossible-to-remember-or-type password!

column2: Once your password has been cracked, it can be used across other sites too.
